Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: In an update at Wednesday’s school board meeting, parents, students and school staff demanded transparency and answers about why they were kept in the dark.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: parents, students and school staff were directly affected by the delayed communication about lead contamination in school water and are stakeholders in the issue.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Community members, many of whom raised concerns two weeks ago, were skeptical.
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Community members are stakeholders in the issue and have been raising concerns about the district's handling of the lead contamination.

Unnamed Group of People.Sourced Statement: Teachers from Frick United Academy of Language demanded to know why, if testing took place in April, fountains weren’t shut down until August.
Unnamed Group of People.Name of Source: Teachers from Frick United Academy of Language
Unnamed Group of People.Source Justification: Teachers from Frick United Academy of Language are directly impacted by the lead contamination issue and are questioning the district's delayed response.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: An average of two months passed between when Oakland schools were tested for lead this spring and when those school communities were notified of high lead levels in August, according to a report from this week’s Oakland Unified school board meeting.
Document Sources.Name of Source: Oakland Unified school board meeting report
Document Sources.Source Justification: The report from the Oakland Unified school board meeting provides data on the timeline of lead testing and notification.

Document Sources.Sourced Statement: In stage two, 15 elementary schools were tested between Aug. 17 and Aug. 22, requiring six fixtures to be repaired, according to the report.
Document Sources.Name of Source: Oakland Unified school board meeting report
Document Sources.Source Justification: The report provides details on the testing and repair process for water fixtures in stage two of the district's plan.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “This mistake has caused families stress, anxiety and panic, further limiting our community’s trust in this district,” said Max Simmons, one of OUSD’s student directors.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Max Simmons is a student director at OUSD, providing a perspective on the impact of the district's actions on the community.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “I sincerely apologize for the stress and concern this has caused our school sites, students and families. We understand the gravity of this situation and we are fully committed to taking immediate, transparent and corrective action,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Kyla Johnson-Trammell is the Superintendent of OUSD, addressing the district's response to the lead contamination issue.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “There is so much trust rebuilding that has to be done for our community. We have failed. And when I say ‘we’ I mean OUSD has failed at its most basic job of not poisoning our students,” said Stuart Loebl, a sixth-grade science teacher at Frick.
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Stuart Loebl is a teacher directly affected by the lead contamination issue, providing a critical perspective on the district's handling of the situation.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “Why didn’t you do your job? You knew months ago that the water was contaminated. You didn’t act, and you let those kids come back to school and drink poisoned water,” said Marina Muñoz, a parent at Madison Park Academy and an organizer with Communities for a Better Environment.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: parent at Madison Park Academy and an organizer with Communities for a Better Environment
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Marina Muñoz is a parent and community organizer, directly addressing the district's delayed response to the lead contamination issue.

Named Person Sources.Sourced Statement: “This is not new to Oakland, but it is something that we need to tackle as an entire city, and we need to have community partners, philanthropic partners, as well as our county and state folks to support us in dealing with this issue,” she said.
Named Person Sources.Title of Source: Director and chair of OUSD’s facilities committee
Named Person Sources.Source Justification: Valarie Bachelor is the chair of OUSD’s facilities committee, discussing the broader implications and solutions for the lead contamination issue.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: The district’s risk management team began testing water fixtures and faucets in April and continued through the summer, but it wasn’t until Aug. 10 that district officials realized school sites hadn’t been told about it or informed of the results.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The Oakland Unified School District is responsible for the testing and communication regarding lead contamination in school water.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: District leadership — including Superintendent Kyla Johnson-Trammell, chief systems and services officer Preston Thomas, and risk management officer Rebecca Littlejohn — committed to transparency going forward and said a personnel investigation is underway to determine how communication broke down.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The Oakland Unified School District leadership is addressing the communication breakdown and committing to transparency.

Named Organization Sources.Sourced Statement: District leaders on Wednesday said the lead came from the water fixtures, such as a sink faucet or water fountain spigot, and denied that it was an issue with pipes or the water source.
Named Organization Sources.Source Justification: The Oakland Unified School District is providing technical details about the source of the lead contamination.
